newsitem.title: USA: Union Carbide says earnings hurt by rising material costs.
newsitem.headline: Union Carbide says earnings hurt by rising material costs.

text.p: Union Carbide Corp. reported sharply lower profits for the latest quarter Monday, blaming the downturn on rising raw material and energy costs.
The giant chemicals manufacturer said its earnings slumped to $102 million, or 74 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with year-earlier earnings of $190 million, or $1.33 a share.
The drop in profits came despite a jump in sales to $1.50 billion from $1.34 billion.
Wall Street, which had been looking for a even bigger drop in per share profits, to 66 cents, boosted Union Carbide's stock by 25 cents at $44.125 in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

"Although volumes were strong for the quarter, and Carbide did a good job of controlling fixed costs, results were hurt by significantly higher raw material costs, especially ethane costs, which more than doubled since the same period in 1995," said Union Carbide Chairman and Chief Executive Officer William Joyce.
